item.title: Topic 5: Naturalism
item.description: Does evolution favor selfish behavior as organisms pursue survival and reproduction in a competitive environment? Alternatively, what if we are ethical, but only because ethics is merely a behavior we’ve evolved to exhibit? Would that make it a sham? Can competing organisms rationally cooperate? Reading “Evolutionary Theory” by Simon Blackburn, in Being Good, pages 37–43. Listen to “Cooperation and Conflict,” by Philosophy Talk Starters via SoundCloud. (10 min, 35 seconds)1 See also “Tit for Tat” podcast episode by Radiolab, WNYC Studios (27 min) “Four Ways of Biologicizing Ethics,” by Philip Kitcher (1993), available here “Prisoner’s Dilemma” at Stanford Encyclopedia of Encyclopedia “Game Theory” at Stanford Encyclopedia of Encyclopedia “Evolutionary Game Theory” at Stanford Encyclopedia of Encyclopedia “Game Theory and Ethics” at Stanford Encyclopedia of Encyclopedia There’s a full version of this episode available for purchase at the Philosophy Talk website, but you’re not required to buy it.

item.title: Topic 4: Egoism
item.description: Are we completely selfish? Can we do anything genuinely altruistic—for others' benefit? If we are selfish, like Glaucon’s descriptive argument suggests, pursuing only our own pleasure, philosophical ethics looks like a sham. Is it? Reading “Egoism” by Simon Blackburn in Being Good (purchased book), pages 29–37. brief excerpts from “Psychological Egoism” by Joel Feinberg (1958), available on Blackboard > Course Documents. Learning questions What’s a reason to think that human beings are selfish?

item.title: Topic 3: Relativism
item.description: Reading “The Challenge of Cultural Relativism” by James Rachels. 1986. from The Elements of Moral Philosophy Temple University Press. Available through the course’s Blackboard site (under Course Documents). Note: this text, like some others we’ll read, includes some outdated language, like “Eskimo”—a word some of those it is used to refer to find unacceptable; I suggest not using it. Learning questions What’s the difference between general relativism and moral relativism?

item.title: Topic 2: God
item.description: What is ethics if there is no God, or, What would become of ethics if there were no God? If there is a God, does that make all further ethical discussion superfluous? Reading “The Death of God” from Being Good, by Simon Blackburn, pages 9–19. (This is the one book you need to purchase for this course.) Euthyphro (excerpt from Reginald Allen’s translation), by Plato. Available through Hofstra library here, login required.

item.title: Topic 1: The Problem of Justice
item.description: Are there any reasons not to behave unjustly, if we can get away with it? We observe Plato asking this question through a “thought experiment.” Reading Plato, “The Ring of Gyges,” an excerpt from his longer work Republic. See also “Plato” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, by Richard Kraut “Plato’s Ethics and Politics in The Republic” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, by Eric “Brown”

item.title: Participation Rubric
item.description: This is the participation rubric to be used for grading participation in this course. Read it as saying “A student who demonstrates … earns a grade of X,” where X is the letter grade at the top of the column.1 A B C D F Active role in discussions, drawing on texts Regular, constructive participation drawing on texts Inconsistent constructive participation based on texts Vague comments reflecting limited engagement with texts Persistent lack of engagement with texts Full preparation for approximately every class Substantial preparation, normally Inconsistent evidence of preparation Rare evidence of participation No positive evidence of participation Success at advancing level and depth of discussion, persistently Regular contributions based on assigned material, which sometimes improve discussion and never diminish it Rare or no significant contribution to the level of discussion while not reducing it Activity sometimes diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Activity regularly diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Active engagement with and listening to peers, persistently Sincere efforts to interact with peers, normally Limited engagement with peers Rare interaction with peers No interaction with peers This rubric is significantly based on, and lightly adapted from, one written by another philosophy professor, Jay Odenbaugh.
